Author: petercooper
Content:
I've always done what you outline. It works great for me, and I like having many fingers in many pies, but I'm pretty convinced it only works because of my personality.

Would Google, Microsoft or Apple be where they are now if the founders had decided to work on several things at once? All reasonably single minded people involved there who threw their all into their respective companies.

I'm never going to found a 8 or 9 figure revenue company because I don't want to be that focused or that single minded. Fine for me, but the people who do want that option are probably best off not dating more than one girl, right?

Author: time_management
Content:
It is not clear to me whether you should date lots of girls, or just know lots of girls who you could date if your current relationship falls apart.

I'm pretty sure his use of the word "date" means "going on dates with", not "be in a relationship with". Having 2+ girlfriends is a bad idea, especially if you're starting a company.

Author: time_management
Content:
The analogy you're making reminds me of the quote, "VCs are like women: they only want you if others do."

You're absolutely correct that, before a deal is sealed (signed term sheet, or relationship) in either arena, it makes sense not only to keep open as many options as possible, but also to seek out more open options. Your "game" will failbox if you only have one prospect, because this person has an incredible amount of power over you. Of course, eventually, you have to take the plunge and commit to one.

However, the analogy between women and funding is pretty weak. The most obvious difference is that sources of funding are pretty much interchangeable, and it's utterly necessary to get some sort of funding, so it makes sense to jump on the first reasonable offer. Women, on the other hand, are decidedly not interchangeable, while there's no need to be in a relationship, so it makes sense to be picky and hold out for an exceptionally good match.

Author: jacobscott
Content:
It is not clear to me whether you should date lots of girls, or just know lots of girls who you could date if your current relationship falls apart.

I think I agree when it comes to clients and investors, but in terms of major technical (or business-plan type) components, once you have multiple avenues you'll need more resources, more planning, and it seems like you'll inevitably lose focus.

Date lots of women but only marry one?

Author: josefresco
Content: I'm not worried... for every home owner who bought an overpriced home, is another home owner who sold them that home.

Author: petercooper
Content:
but these are all superficial next to the damage done by all the absolutely atrocious Perl code out there.

The writer argues that Perl's being damaged by bad code examples, but if that were the case, PHP would be the least popular language in the world, no?

Perl's troubles are not just because of bad code examples, because the language is poorly constructed (in terms of v5, v6 is a lot better), or because its marketing is poor/non-existent.. but because of all of these things and many other issues beside (especially the difficulty of deployment). These issues are enough to make one jump ship after years of non-resolution.

(I was a nearly full-time Perl developer from 1996-2005 - haven't touched it at all in the last few years since I jumped ship to Ruby, so it's not as if I'm hating on the language without having once loved it ;-))

Author: jhancock
Content:
Its only the end of VC if you think that VCs only invest in Internet start-ups. Its great that its become vastly cheaper to create a new Internet product.

There are many other industries that can make use of VC; green tech, for example. VC isn't dying, its just going to focus on different industry segments.

Author: frisco
Content:
You're absolutely right, it's way more likely here, and that's probably what's going on. Whether there's credible evidence or not as to a Google OS wasn't my point -- it's that the _idea_ of Google doing that wouldn't strike you as crazy, and that just brings up the question "what could they do with it?"

Linus did a very, very good job for the single isolated box. A kernel that had very deep ties to a greater infrastructure, a true internet computer, though, would have a huge value proposition for a lot of users, especially in business. I guess this thread could have been better titled, "Challenge HN: Extend the Linux kernel to do low level process splitting and handle a remote file system natively, to have the computer run partially on a distributed infrastructure as needed." I'd be amazed if Google aren't the ones to do this. If they aren't, though, we'll be welcoming some new names to the computing billionaires' club in the next few years.
